name: Frank Overton (FasCat)
description: Sweet Spot methodology with power-based periodization and fatigue-dependent design. Emphasizes aerobic base building through sub-threshold work and systematic recovery weeks.
author: Based on FasCat Coaching philosophy and Frank Overton's methodology

philosophy.notes: Sweet Spot training (84-97% FTP) as primary tool. Uses Performance Manager Chart for load management. Rest weeks every 3-4 weeks at 50% volume. Builds aerobic engine first, then race-specific work.

adjust_intensity_up: Power is stable and HR looks good. Raise targets by {{percent}}% to hit Sweet Spot more effectively?
adjust_intensity_up_rationale: Power and cadence are steady in the Sweet Spot with minimal HR drift. You're handling this load well and can push slightly harder while staying productive.
adjust_intensity_down: Power below target with HR drift rising. Let's reduce by {{percent}}% to stay in the productive zone.
adjust_intensity_down_rationale: Power is below Sweet Spot target and HR drift indicates rising fatigue. Reducing intensity will keep you in the productive aerobic zone rather than fighting a losing battle.
extend_recovery: HR still elevated from previous block. Extend recovery by {{seconds}} seconds to come back fresh?
extend_recovery_rationale: Your recovery HR is still elevated from the last Sweet Spot effort. Extra recovery time now ensures quality in the remaining intervals rather than digging a deeper hole.
skip_remaining_on_intervals: Fatigue is building and power is dropping. Skip remaining intervals and cool down to fight another day?
skip_remaining_on_intervals_rationale: Multiple intervals show declining power with elevated HR drift and you've rejected intensity reductions. This indicates significant fatigue. Better to save the remaining CTL for tomorrow's session.

completion: Session complete. Solid Sweet Spot work today.
Nice work. That's how you build an aerobic base.
